comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: This 1905 New York Times article is headlined "JACKIES' SCHOOL. There They Learn How to Be Yeomen in the U.S. Navy." The article is about the yeoman's school which was then at Brooklyn Navy Yard. My guess would be that "Jacky" was derived from "Jack Tar", but I've been unable to find an etymology on the Internet.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content:
whyaduck:

Thank you for your information. It looks like you could be correct about the U.S. Navy recruits. We will add the information to the source data and reload the description.

comment.author: 42264328@N00
comment._content: whyaduck--that sounds correct for "Jacky". Here are some song lyrics referring to Jacky Tar or Jackie Tar. A quote from the liner notes on one album says: A Jacky Tar is a name for a sailor. Partridge's Concise Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English (New York: MacMillan, 1989) has an entry for Jackies = "American Sailors", and notes usage since at least 1942--clearly it was in use earlier. The usage seems to have gone from "Jack Tar" to "Jackie Tar" to Jackies.

comment.author: 36899742@N00
comment._content: Reverse handwriting at bottom says, "Inauguration Wash 1913," so this was part of Wilson's first inaugural parade.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Noel Zia Lee: Thanks for the information about the reverse handwriting which reveals the context of this image.  We will update the source data and reload the description.
